Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development of song culture in zebra finches - vocal and sensory changes over generations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Culture consists of traits transmitted through social learning. One example for social learning is the acquisition of song by songbirds: During a sensitive period early in life, young males learn to imitate their father's song. Songbirds provide tractable models of culture: Members of a species show individual variation in song, and geographically separated groups have local song dialects, i.e., a local song culture. How does song culture develop over multiple generations? In zebra finches, birds kept isolated during the sensitive period develop an abnormal (isolate) song. Interestingly, in an isolated colony founded by an isolate, "normal" songs with species-typical features emerge within 3-4 generations, due to biased imitation that gradually transforms the isolate song into the species-typical song. Understanding how song develops in individual birds and how song culture develops in a community might require knowledge not only about the vocal, but also about the sensory-perceptual development across generations, as well as the social interactions which accompany it. This project is a combined study of social, vocal, and sensory aspects of song development. The investigators will design controlled social environments to examine dynamically how song is acquired and how song culture emerges. They will combine the continuous analysis of vocal changes and social interactions with non-invasive functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) of the brain to investigate how auditory brain responses to songs develop, and how they drive cultural changes. Moreover, these researchers will test if developmental changes in brain architecture correlate with observed vocal and/or sensory changes using diffusion tensor imaging (DTI).

This research will provide a bridge between studies of vocal and sensory changes and ethology studies of cultural changes in vocal communication. This project will contribute to the training of three graduate students, and provide scientific education and research training to undergraduate students as well as middle and high school students in the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mechanisms of song learning and production in songbirds can tell us something about speech. Experiments to study song learning in zebra finches, a song bird, therefore offer insights into the development of speech and language, as well as into speech motor control disorders such as developmental stuttering. It is of particular importance to understand how experience causes the brain to develop song learning, perception and production. The just completed project undertaken by me in a joint effort with the laboratories of Ofer Tchernichovski at Hunter College and Santosh Helekar at the Houston Methodist Research Institution was aimed at studying how social interactions affect the learning of song by young zebra finches from their adult teachers or tutors, and how the development of the ability of the brain to process vocal sounds impacts the development of songs produced by these birds. My contribution to this effort consisted in the development of methods to measure brain responses to sound stimuli, including bird songs, and the changes that occur in these responses from short periods of time to longer times, even over generations. In particular, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and positron emission tomography (PET) in zebra finches, methods that we adapted from their widespread use in humans to the small zebra finch brain.

 

FMRI showed that in young zebra finches the highest detectable levels of neuronal activation in response to birdsongs were seen in the main auditory areas of the brain, and these neuronal responses became more intense over short periods of time after repeated exposure to these sounds. The increase in responses was more pronounced when a bird was exposed to a new song. It was further accentuated if the song contained abnormal repetitions of a song component, making it superficially similar to stuttered speech. Those songs occur in a small percentage of birds that we call repeater birds. We found that the brain responses to the tutor’s song were significantly weaker in repeater birds. We also found that the strength of the response to tutor’s song in repeater birds correlated with the degree of similarity of this song to the bird’s own song.

 

The experimental fMRI procedures developed for zebra finches were also adapted to study vocalization in other species. As a result, in collaboration with the group of Srivatsun Sadagopan at The Rockefeller University, we discovered a brain map for the processing of vocalizations in marmosets. Our results demonstrate similar mechanisms of vocalization processing in macaques and marmosets, suggesting that brain structures for vocal processing have evolved before the lineages of these species diverged.

 

The setup of PET experiments to image the neurotransmitter dopamine and its response to bird song stimuli required a completely different design. In first experiments on zebra finches we worked out the optimum protocol for imaging dopamine uptake in the brain after stimulation with bird song. We have found a method that allows us to image the immediate effects of stimulation under natural conditions, important for obtaining data not biased by unwanted factors that might also affect dopamine levels such as stress. We also worked out new statistical analysis methods specifically adapted to these imaging experiments. Besides the new experimental procedures that can be used in other labs, too, our research resulted in important findings regarding dopaminergic activity in the song bird brain. For example, we have found that bird song increases dopaminergic activity in different ways in zebra finch females and males, which we hypothesize is due to different roles in their mating and breeding cycle.
